ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to communicate using basic Spanish, through both reading and writing.
Communication and writing skills.

I have taken Spanish throughout high school and middle school (receiving high marks) but was ultimately placed into Spanish 110 at Yale. I was pretty surprised about my placement, and was unsure if the level was right for me, but I decided to continue anyway since I have always wanted to be fluent in Spanish. Throughout this semester, I have learned more about Spanish than I ever did in my old school district. I feel comfortable speaking, and can't wait to learn more in subsequent courses.
I developed a good understanding of beginner Spanish and how to be more comfortable with speaking Spanish. I also write much better than I expected.

I developed alot of knowledge as a student in this course. I didn't only learn basic Spanish, but I also learned plenty of knowledge about Spanish culture. As part of learning a new language, I was able to build upon my critical thinking skills and refine my study skills.
Learning vocabulary
It helped me really understand the language and be able to be proficient in speaking the language.
You quickly learn a basic level of Spanish from scratch, enough to speak simple sentences in multiple tense.
elementary spanish

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The strengths of this course are that heavy participation is required so you're forced to learn a lot of Spanish in a short amount of time. I do think there could be slightly less homework.
I really like how students are forced to speak spanish inside the classroom.

Strengths: Linguameeting, Supersite, course instruction, small class sizes
Weaknesses: discussion posts (found them to be "busy work")

I like that the professor provided grammar and vocabulary slides on Canvas and I felt that he really cared. I did not like the set up of the three exams and that there was not time to review because of how fast the course went.

One strength of this course was having one asynchronous day a week. I appreciated this opportunity as it allowed me to study vocabulary and complete class assignments. Another strength of this course was its small size. I engaged in frequent discussions with both my classmates and my professor, and the professor got to know all of us very well. However, one weakness was the workload during the beginning and middle of the course. There was alot of homework and quizzes during this section of the class, and it was a heavier workload in comparison to the other classes I was taking at the time. However, the workload for this class became more balanced, especially towards the end of the course.
Speaking Spanish, listening to Spanish speakers

The strength of the course was that I think it was very engaging and helped me learn the language all at the same time. The weakness was that there were some times that it was very slow when I felt like everyone knew what we were doing.

Strengths: properly facilitates language learning!
Weaknesses: too much busy work

strength: consistency will daily classes
weaknesses: overloaded with work sometimes. We learned a lot of Spanish very quickly, so if you were still practicing or needed help with a concept, there wasn't any time to catch up. There are also students who are more advanced in L1 that make learning altogether a bit more intimidating.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, because I was always encouraged to keep trying to learn even if I made a lot of mistakes.
Yes, especially with Ian Russell!
Yes I would. I think learning a new language is important and Spanish is among the most well-known languages in the world.
Yes, I feel much more confident in my Spanish language skills.
Yes because it is a great way to begin learning Spanish.

I would recommend this course to another student (particularly with this professor) because you learn alot about the Spanish language and culture. The intimate and supportive learning environment, along with the frequency at which you write, hear, and speak the language allows you to become more immersed in your learning. As someone who didn't take Spanish in high school, taking this class has improved my Spanish speaking and writing abilities while making me more confident about having conversations with Spanish speakers.
Yes
I would recommend this to any student that really does want to learn Spanish because it is a very work heavy course and you have to stay caught up all the time.
Absolutely!
yes, it's just fast
